articles.headline: In European Debt Crisis, Some Call Default Better Option
articles.snippet: Many economic experts say that bailouts only delay the inevitable and that governments should work toward organized restructuring of debts.
articles.abstract: Many economic experts say that bailouts only delay the inevitable and that governments should work toward organized restructuring of debts.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — Ireland has finally taken its medicine, accepting the financial rescue package European officials have been pushing for several weeks.

articles.headline: After the Nuclear Plant Powers Down
articles.snippet: Instead of hiring a contractor, Exelon has turned the job and the reactors over to a nuclear demolition company.
articles.abstract: Instead of hiring a contractor, Exelon has turned the job and the reactors over to a nuclear demolition company.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZION, Ill.  Twelve years ago, Commonwealth Edison found itself in a bind.

articles.headline: Campus That Apartheid Ruled Faces a Policy Rift
articles.snippet: The University of Cape Town is engaged in a searching debate about just how far affirmative action should go to heal the wounds of apartheid.
articles.abstract: The University of Cape Town is engaged in a searching debate about just how far affirmative action should go to heal the wounds of apartheid.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAPE TOWN  The University of Cape Town was once a citadel of white privilege on the majestic slopes of Devil’s Peak. At the height of apartheid, it admitted few black or mixed-race students, and they were barred from campus dormitories, even forbidden to attend medical school postmortems on white corpses.

articles.headline: Radiation Worries for Children in Dentists’ Chairs
articles.snippet: Children are vulnerable to radiation, but dentists and orthodontists use technology that emits high levels of it.
articles.abstract: Children are vulnerable to radiation, but dentists and orthodontists use technology that emits high levels of it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Because children and adolescents are particularly vulnerable to radiation, doctors three years ago mounted a national campaign to protect them by reducing diagnostic radiation to only those levels seen as absolutely necessary.
articles.byline: By Walt Bogdanich and Jo Craven McGinty

articles.headline: Fed Adopts Political Tactics on Critics
articles.snippet: Facing a hyperpartisan environment, the central bank is trying to defend its policy moves without becoming overtly political, and is adopting insider strategies to do so.
articles.abstract: Facing a hyperpartisan environment, the central bank is trying to defend its policy moves without becoming overtly political, and is adopting insider strategies to do so.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Faced with unusually sharp ideological attacks after its latest bid to stimulate the economy, the Federal Reserve now faces a challenge far removed from the conduct of monetary policy: how to defend itself in a hyperpartisan environment without becoming overtly political.

articles.headline: Taliban Leader in Secret Talks Was an Impostor
articles.snippet: A man purporting to be a key figure in the talks was faking, American and Afghan officials say.
articles.abstract: A man purporting to be a key figure in the talks was faking, American and Afghan officials say.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  For months, the secret talks unfolding between Taliban and Afghan leaders to end the war appeared to be showing promise, if only because of the appearance of a certain insurgent leader at one end of the table: Mullah Akhtar Muhammad Mansour, one of the most senior commanders in the Taliban movement.
articles.byline: By Dexter Filkins and Carlotta Gall

articles.headline: At a Checkpoint, Terror Fears and Testy Travelers
articles.snippet: It can be argued that the T.S.A. has failed in customer relations.
articles.abstract: It can be argued that the T.S.A. has failed in customer relations.

articles.headline: Irish Debt Crisis Forces Collapse of Government
articles.snippet: A day after signing off on a $100 billion bailout, Prime Minister Brian Cowen said he would dissolve the government next month.
articles.abstract: A day after signing off on a $100 billion bailout, Prime Minister Brian Cowen said he would dissolve the government next month.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — The Irish government faced imminent collapse on Monday, only a day after it signed off on a $100 billion bailout, setting the stage for a new election early next year and injecting the threat of political instability into a European financial crisis that already has markets on edge.

articles.headline: U.S. Home Sales Fell Sharply in October
articles.snippet: In an early taste of what the real estate market might look like with foreclosures stalled and a big tax credit gone, sales of existing homes plunged 26 percent in October.
articles.abstract: In an early taste of what the real estate market might look like with foreclosures stalled and a big tax credit gone, sales of existing homes plunged 26 percent in October.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the last few years, buyers have been lured into the troubled housing market by two unusual opportunities: cash subsidies in the form of government tax credits, and rock-bottom prices on millions of foreclosed homes.
